 July 9, 2002. 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 
 A citizenship judge held that Hassan did not qualify for citizenship because, inter alia, Hassan did not have adequate knowledge of either official language. Hassan appealed. 
 
 
 
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, in a decision not reported in this series of reports allowed the appeal and remitted the matter to a new citizenship judge to consider whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister to waive the knowledge requirements on compassionate grounds or with regard to any special or undue hardship. The citizenship judge reconsidered the matter and held that Hassan lacked the necessary knowledge to be given citizenship. Hassan appealed. 
 
 
 
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, allowed the appeal and remitted the matter to a new citizenship judge to consider whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister. 
 
 
 
 Aliens - Topic 2526.2 
 
 Naturalization - Qualifications - Knowledge of one official language - A citizenship judge was directed to consider whether to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister to waive the knowledge requirements for citizenship - Hassan's inability to learn a new language was to be taken into account - The citizenship judge held that Hassan lacked the necessary knowledge to be given citizenship - The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, allowed Hassan's appeal because the citizenship judge failed to understand the medical evidence that Hassan was unable to take advantage of an adult English language education program because of a learning disability. 
 
 
 
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.), refd to. [para. 12]. 
 
 Khat, Re (1991), 49 F.T.R. 252 (T.D.), refd to. [para. 14]. 
 
 
 
 Counsel: 
 
 Max Berger, for the applicant; 
 
 Greg George, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 This appeal was heard at Toronto, Ontario, on June 28, 2002, before Kelen, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, who released the following reasons for order on July 9, 2002. 
 
 
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Kelen, J. 
 : This is an appeal pursuant to s. 14(5) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 , R.S.C., 1985, c. C-29 (the " 
 Act 
 ") from the decision of the Citizenship Judge Doreen Wicks, dated April 28, 2000, finding that the applicant did not qualify for citizenship.

[2] 
  The issue in this appeal is whether the Citizenship Judge failed to properly consider relevant factors and misapprehended the evidence in a capricious or perverse manner in the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  with respect to the applicant's medical inability to learn English. 
 
 
 
 FACTS

[3] 
  The applicant is a citizen of Somalia and permanent resident of Canada. On September 30, 1997, she was denied citizenship for the first time. As grounds for the refusal, Citizenship Judge Alice Napier found that the applicant was unable to "understand and respond to simple questions in either official language".

[4] 
  The applicant appealed the refusal. By decision dated September 29, 1999 this court referred her application for citizenship for reconsideration as to whether a recommendation pursuant to s. 15(1) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
  should be made. The court directed that new medical evidence as to the applicant's inability to learn a new language should be taken into account.

[5] 
  The matter was reconsidered by Citizenship Judge Doreen Wicks. In a letter dated April 28, 2000, the judge decided that the applicant "... did not have adequate knowledge of Canada, and/or the responsibilities and privileges of Citizenship.". The judge further found that the applicant "did not have adequate knowledge of English or French.". Referring to ss. 5(1)(d), 14 and 15 of the  
 Act 
 , the judge found that the applicant lacked the necessary knowledge to be given citizenship.

[6] 
  The judge considered an exercise of discretion under s. 5(3), 5(4) and 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  to waive the knowledge requirements on "compassionate grounds" or with regard to any "special or unusual hardship".

[7] 
  The judge specifically referred to the "medical opinion" which discusses Mrs. Hassan illiteracy and complete lack of schooling, and that an adult literacy program is not appropriate. The Citizenship Judge stated at page 2 of her decision: 
 
 
 
 "The medical opinion states that you had never been schooled and therefore your doctor suggested that being thrust into an adult literacy program as an adult is not appropriate. I have met many applicants who have been in the same situation and have at least used the incredible Link programs we have to offer immigrants at no cost and who benefit from such teaching. 
 
 
 
 "In my opinion you have many opportunities in Canada to improve on your education. 
 
 
 
 "Pursuant to s. 14(3) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 , you are, therefore, advised that, for the above reasons, your application for Citizenship is not approved."

[8] 
  The "medical opinion" is that of Issac Smith, M.A., who rendered an opinion with respect to "neuropsychological screening". Mr. Smith is not a medical doctor. He is certified as a "Psychological Associate" by the College of Psychologists of Ontario. Mr. Smith's report states that the applicant has: 
 
 
 
 "[...] the virtual total absence of organizational, orientating and analytic skills which underlie written language. These sorts of skills are really 'foundation' skills which predate and underlie the acquisition of written language itself, and are typically developed very early in a person's educational history."

[9] 
  Mr. Smith writes that the majority of individuals in adult English language programs have foundations skills which they acquired when they learned their native language, and that Mrs. Hassan does not have these foundation skills to assist her to learn English in an adult education program. Mr. Smith also states that the neuropsychological functioning of her brain, at her age of 52 years, does not have the capacity for "new learning".

[10] 
  Additional evidence was placed before the court, including a letter from an adult LINC instructor of the Toronto District School Board dated January 11, 1999 confirming that the applicant has been a student of English in the LINC program since September, 1997, and since that time has made no progress and is confused by the language. This evidence was not before the Citizenship Judge and therefore cannot properly be considered by this court. The next Citizenship Judge to consider this case will have the benefit of this evidence. 
 
 
 
 THE LAW

[11] 
  The relevant sections of the  
 Act 
  are as follows: 
 
 
 
 "5(1) The Minister shall grant citizenship to any person who ... 
 
 
 
 (d) has an adequate knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada; 
 
 
 
 (e) has an adequate knowledge of Canada and of the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(3) The Minister may, in his discretion, waive on compassionate grounds, 
 
 
 
 (a) in the case of any person, the requirements of paragraph (1)(d) or (e); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(4) In order to alleviate cases of special and unusual hardship or to reward services of an exceptional value to Canada, and notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, the Governor in Council may, in his discretion, direct the Minister to grant citizenship to any person and, where such a direction is made, the Minister shall forthwith grant citizenship to the person named in the direction. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "14(1) An application for 
 
 
 
 (a) a grant of citizenship under subsection 5(1), 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 shall be considered by a citizenship judge who shall, within sixty days of the day the application was referred to the judge, determine whether or not the person who made the application meets the requirements of this Act and the regulations with respect to the application. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(2) Forthwith after making a determination under subsection (1) in respect of an application referred to therein but subject to section 15, the citizenship judge shall approve or not approve the application in accordance with his determination, notify the Minister accordingly and provide the Minister with the reasons therefor. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(5) The Minister or the applicant may appeal to the court from the decision of the citizenship judge under subsection (2) by filing a notice of appeal in the Registry of the Court within sixty days after the day on which 
 
 
 
 (a) the citizenship judge approved the application under subsection (2); gold 
 
 
 
 (b) notice was mailed or otherwise given under subsection (3) with respect to the application. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "15(1) Where a citizenship judge is unable to approve an application under subsection 14(2), the judge shall, 
 
 
 
 before deciding not to approve it, consider whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion under subsection 5(3) or (4) or subsection 9(2) as the circumstances may require." 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 "5(1) The Minister shall grant citizenship to any person who: ... 
 
 
 
 (d) has sufficient knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada; 
 
 
 
 (e) has sufficient knowledge of Canada and the responsibilities and benefits conferred by citizenship; 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(3) For humanitarian reasons, the Minister has the discretionary power to exempt: 
 
 
 
 (a) in all cases, the conditions set out in paragraph (1)(d) or (e); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(4) In order to remedy a particular and unusual situation of distress or to reward exceptional services rendered to Canada, the Governor in Council has the discretionary power, despite the other provisions of this Act, to order the Minister to grant citizenship to any person he designates; the Minister shall then proceed without delay to the grant. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "14(1) Within sixty days of referral, the citizenship judge rules on the conformity - with the provisions applicable in the case of this law and its regulations - of the applications filed with a view to: 
 
 
 
 (a) the grant of citizenship, under subsection 5(1); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(2) Immediately after ruling on the application referred to in paragraph (1), the citizenship judge, subject to section 15, approves or rejects the application depending on whether or not he concludes that it is compliant and transmits his reasoned decision to the Minister. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(5) The Minister and the applicant may appeal the decision of the citizenship judge by filing a notice of appeal with the Registry of the Court within sixty days following the date, as the case may be: 
 
 
 
 (a) approval of the application; 
 
 
 
 b) communication, by mail or any other means, of the rejection decision. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "15(1) Before rendering a refusal decision, the citizenship judge shall consider whether it is appropriate to recommend the exercise of the discretionary power provided for in subsections 5(3) or (4) or 9(2), as the case may be." 
 
 
 
 ANALYSIS 
 
 
 
 Jurisdiction

[12] 
  This is an appeal pursuant to s. 14(5) of the  
 Act 
  which is restricted to a decision under s. 14(2). There is no appeal under the  
 Act 
  from the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1). Nadon, J. (as he then was), held at paragraph 15 and 16 in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.), that the power exercised by the Citizenship Judge under s. 15(1) is not a decision under s. 14(2) and this court is without jurisdiction over the matter. Justice Nadon stated that the only remedy open to the applicant to review the exercise of discretion under s. 15(1) is by way of judicial review.

[13] 
  judges of this court have assumed jurisdiction to consider appeals with respect to the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1). For that reason, the appellant reasonably brought the matter before this court. On this basis, and to avoid redundancy of legal proceedings, I will assume jurisdiction to avoid creating the absurd result where the applicant would be required to bring an application for judicial review under s. 18.1 of the  
 Federal Court Act 
  and seek an extension of time in doing so (which I would grant in the circumstances). 
 
 
 
 Review of the Citizenship Judge's discretion

[14] 
  In this case, Justice Reed has already reviewed the earlier Citizenship Judge's decision and allowed the appeal with a direction that it be reconsidered by another Citizenship Judge based on the medical evidence. The leading case where the court has agreed to review the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1) is  
 Khat, Re 
 , [1991] F.C.J. No. 949; 49 F.T.R. 252 (T.D.), per Strayer, J.: 
 
 
 
 "Section 14(2) provides, however, that as a precondition to making a decision under that subsection, the citizenship judge must consider whether or not to make a recommendation under s. 15(1). While it is not for this court, sitting on appeal, to review the conclusion of the citizenship judge as to whether a recommendation should be made,  
 in a proper case it may be open to this court to refer the matter back to the citizenship judge if this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account in the exercise of that discretion. 
 " (Emphasis added)

[15] 
  Following  
 Khat 
 , supra., it is open to this court to refer the matter back to the Citizenship Judge if this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account in the exercise of discretion under s. 15(1).

[16] 
  I am persuaded that the Citizenship Judge in the case at bar either failed to consider relevant evidence or misapprehended the "medical" evidence. For this reason, I am satisfied that relevant factors where not taken into account in the exercise of discretion. The Citizenship Judge compares the applicant to other applicants who have used the "incredible Link program" (sic) and that the applicant has "many opportunities in Canada to improve your education". This is a patently unreasonable finding of fact made without regard to the evidence. This finding of fact is perverse in that the "medical evidence" establishes that the appellant does not have the foundation skills to be able to use the LINC program, i.e. adult English language education.

[17] 
  The Citizenship decision also misunderstands the fact that the applicant has been enrolled in the LINC program for two years. Regardless of whether the letter from the LINC instructor was before the Citizenship Judge, it is clear that the Citizenship Judge failed to understand that the Mrs. Hassan has taken advantage of the opportunity to improve her education, but is mentally unable to take advantage of this opportunity because of her learning disability.

[18] 
  Accordingly, this is a proper case, in accordance with  
 Khat 
 , supra, to refer the matter to a new Citizenship Judge because this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account, namely the mental inability of the applicant to benefit from the LINC program and to improve her education in the English language. The court is without jurisdiction to recommend whether the applicant be granted or not granted citizenship. It is noted that nothing in this judgment should be taken to implicitly express an opinion whether or not the applicant ought be recommended for citizenship. That is strictly within the purview, expertise and jurisdiction of the Citizenship Judge reconsidering the case based on proper apprehension of the evidence and relevant factors.

[19] 
  Accordingly, the appeal is allowed. The matter is remitted to a new Citizenship Judge to consider under s. 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister. 
 
 
 
 Appeal allowed. 
 
 
 
 Editor: Rodney A. Jordan/gs 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

 This appeal was heard at Toronto, Ontario, on June 28, 2002, before Kelen, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, who released the following reasons for order on July 9, 2002. 
 
 
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Kelen, J. 
 : This is an appeal pursuant to s. 14(5) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 , R.S.C., 1985, c. C-29 (the " 
 Act 
 ") from the decision of the Citizenship Judge Doreen Wicks, dated April 28, 2000, finding that the applicant did not qualify for citizenship.

[2] 
  The issue in this appeal is whether the Citizenship Judge failed to properly consider relevant factors and misapprehended the evidence in a capricious or perverse manner in the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  with respect to the applicant's medical inability to learn English. 
 
 
 
 FACTS

[3] 
  The applicant is a citizen of Somalia and permanent resident of Canada. On September 30, 1997, she was denied citizenship for the first time. As grounds for the refusal, Citizenship Judge Alice Napier found that the applicant was unable to "understand and respond to simple questions in either official language".

[4] 
  The applicant appealed the refusal. By decision dated September 29, 1999 this court referred her application for citizenship for reconsideration as to whether a recommendation pursuant to s. 15(1) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
  should be made. The court directed that new medical evidence as to the applicant's inability to learn a new language should be taken into account.

[5] 
  The matter was reconsidered by Citizenship Judge Doreen Wicks. In a letter dated April 28, 2000, the judge decided that the applicant "... did not have adequate knowledge of Canada, and/or the responsibilities and privileges of Citizenship.". The judge further found that the applicant "did not have adequate knowledge of English or French.". Referring to ss. 5(1)(d), 14 and 15 of the  
 Act 
 , the judge found that the applicant lacked the necessary knowledge to be given citizenship.

[6] 
  The judge considered an exercise of discretion under s. 5(3), 5(4) and 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  to waive the knowledge requirements on "compassionate grounds" or with regard to any "special or unusual hardship".

[7] 
  The judge specifically referred to the "medical opinion" which discusses Mrs. Hassan illiteracy and complete lack of schooling, and that an adult literacy program is not appropriate. The Citizenship Judge stated at page 2 of her decision: 
 
 
 
 "The medical opinion states that you had never been schooled and therefore your doctor suggested that being thrust into an adult literacy program as an adult is not appropriate. I have met many applicants who have been in the same situation and have at least used the incredible Link programs we have to offer immigrants at no cost and who benefit from such teaching. 
 
 
 
 "In my opinion you have many opportunities in Canada to improve on your education. 
 
 
 
 "Pursuant to s. 14(3) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 , you are, therefore, advised that, for the above reasons, your application for Citizenship is not approved."

[8] 
  The "medical opinion" is that of Issac Smith, M.A., who rendered an opinion with respect to "neuropsychological screening". Mr. Smith is not a medical doctor. He is certified as a "Psychological Associate" by the College of Psychologists of Ontario. Mr. Smith's report states that the applicant has: 
 
 
 
 "[...] the virtual total absence of organizational, orientating and analytic skills which underlie written language. These sorts of skills are really 'foundation' skills which predate and underlie the acquisition of written language itself, and are typically developed very early in a person's educational history."

[9] 
  Mr. Smith writes that the majority of individuals in adult English language programs have foundations skills which they acquired when they learned their native language, and that Mrs. Hassan does not have these foundation skills to assist her to learn English in an adult education program. Mr. Smith also states that the neuropsychological functioning of her brain, at her age of 52 years, does not have the capacity for "new learning".

[10] 
  Additional evidence was placed before the court, including a letter from an adult LINC instructor of the Toronto District School Board dated January 11, 1999 confirming that the applicant has been a student of English in the LINC program since September, 1997, and since that time has made no progress and is confused by the language. This evidence was not before the Citizenship Judge and therefore cannot properly be considered by this court. The next Citizenship Judge to consider this case will have the benefit of this evidence. 
 
 
 
 THE LAW

[11] 
  The relevant sections of the  
 Act 
  are as follows: 
 
 
 
 "5(1) The Minister shall grant citizenship to any person who ... 
 
 
 
 (d) has an adequate knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada; 
 
 
 
 (e) has an adequate knowledge of Canada and of the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(3) The Minister may, in his discretion, waive on compassionate grounds, 
 
 
 
 (a) in the case of any person, the requirements of paragraph (1)(d) or (e); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(4) In order to alleviate cases of special and unusual hardship or to reward services of an exceptional value to Canada, and notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, the Governor in Council may, in his discretion, direct the Minister to grant citizenship to any person and, where such a direction is made, the Minister shall forthwith grant citizenship to the person named in the direction. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "14(1) An application for 
 
 
 
 (a) a grant of citizenship under subsection 5(1), 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 shall be considered by a citizenship judge who shall, within sixty days of the day the application was referred to the judge, determine whether or not the person who made the application meets the requirements of this Act and the regulations with respect to the application. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(2) Forthwith after making a determination under subsection (1) in respect of an application referred to therein but subject to section 15, the citizenship judge shall approve or not approve the application in accordance with his determination, notify the Minister accordingly and provide the Minister with the reasons therefor. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(5) The Minister or the applicant may appeal to the court from the decision of the citizenship judge under subsection (2) by filing a notice of appeal in the Registry of the Court within sixty days after the day on which 
 
 
 
 (a) the citizenship judge approved the application under subsection (2); gold 
 
 
 
 (b) notice was mailed or otherwise given under subsection (3) with respect to the application. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "15(1) Where a citizenship judge is unable to approve an application under subsection 14(2), the judge shall, 
 
 
 
 before deciding not to approve it, consider whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion under subsection 5(3) or (4) or subsection 9(2) as the circumstances may require." 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 "5(1) The Minister shall grant citizenship to any person who: ... 
 
 
 
 (d) has sufficient knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada; 
 
 
 
 (e) has sufficient knowledge of Canada and the responsibilities and benefits conferred by citizenship; 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(3) For humanitarian reasons, the Minister has the discretionary power to exempt: 
 
 
 
 (a) in all cases, the conditions set out in paragraph (1)(d) or (e); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(4) In order to remedy a particular and unusual situation of distress or to reward exceptional services rendered to Canada, the Governor in Council has the discretionary power, despite the other provisions of this Act, to order the Minister to grant citizenship to any person he designates; the Minister shall then proceed without delay to the grant. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "14(1) Within sixty days of referral, the citizenship judge rules on the conformity - with the provisions applicable in the case of this law and its regulations - of the applications filed with a view to: 
 
 
 
 (a) the grant of citizenship, under subsection 5(1); 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(2) Immediately after ruling on the application referred to in paragraph (1), the citizenship judge, subject to section 15, approves or rejects the application depending on whether or not he concludes that it is compliant and transmits his reasoned decision to the Minister. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "(5) The Minister and the applicant may appeal the decision of the citizenship judge by filing a notice of appeal with the Registry of the Court within sixty days following the date, as the case may be: 
 
 
 
 (a) approval of the application; 
 
 
 
 b) communication, by mail or any other means, of the rejection decision. 
 
 
 
 . . . . . 
 
 
 
 "15(1) Before rendering a refusal decision, the citizenship judge shall consider whether it is appropriate to recommend the exercise of the discretionary power provided for in subsections 5(3) or (4) or 9(2), as the case may be." 
 
 
 
 ANALYSIS 
 
 
 
 Jurisdiction

[12] 
  This is an appeal pursuant to s. 14(5) of the  
 Act 
  which is restricted to a decision under s. 14(2). There is no appeal under the  
 Act 
  from the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1). Nadon, J. (as he then was), held at paragraph 15 and 16 in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.), that the power exercised by the Citizenship Judge under s. 15(1) is not a decision under s. 14(2) and this court is without jurisdiction over the matter. Justice Nadon stated that the only remedy open to the applicant to review the exercise of discretion under s. 15(1) is by way of judicial review.

[13] 
  judges of this court have assumed jurisdiction to consider appeals with respect to the exercise of the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1). For that reason, the appellant reasonably brought the matter before this court. On this basis, and to avoid redundancy of legal proceedings, I will assume jurisdiction to avoid creating the absurd result where the applicant would be required to bring an application for judicial review under s. 18.1 of the  
 Federal Court Act 
  and seek an extension of time in doing so (which I would grant in the circumstances). 
 
 
 
 Review of the Citizenship Judge's discretion

[14] 
  In this case, Justice Reed has already reviewed the earlier Citizenship Judge's decision and allowed the appeal with a direction that it be reconsidered by another Citizenship Judge based on the medical evidence. The leading case where the court has agreed to review the Citizenship Judge's discretion under s. 15(1) is  
 Khat, Re 
 , [1991] F.C.J. No. 949; 49 F.T.R. 252 (T.D.), per Strayer, J.: 
 
 
 
 "Section 14(2) provides, however, that as a precondition to making a decision under that subsection, the citizenship judge must consider whether or not to make a recommendation under s. 15(1). While it is not for this court, sitting on appeal, to review the conclusion of the citizenship judge as to whether a recommendation should be made,  
 in a proper case it may be open to this court to refer the matter back to the citizenship judge if this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account in the exercise of that discretion. 
 " (Emphasis added)

[15] 
  Following  
 Khat 
 , supra., it is open to this court to refer the matter back to the Citizenship Judge if this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account in the exercise of discretion under s. 15(1).

[16] 
  I am persuaded that the Citizenship Judge in the case at bar either failed to consider relevant evidence or misapprehended the "medical" evidence. For this reason, I am satisfied that relevant factors where not taken into account in the exercise of discretion. The Citizenship Judge compares the applicant to other applicants who have used the "incredible Link program" (sic) and that the applicant has "many opportunities in Canada to improve your education". This is a patently unreasonable finding of fact made without regard to the evidence. This finding of fact is perverse in that the "medical evidence" establishes that the appellant does not have the foundation skills to be able to use the LINC program, i.e. adult English language education.

[17] 
  The Citizenship decision also misunderstands the fact that the applicant has been enrolled in the LINC program for two years. Regardless of whether the letter from the LINC instructor was before the Citizenship Judge, it is clear that the Citizenship Judge failed to understand that the Mrs. Hassan has taken advantage of the opportunity to improve her education, but is mentally unable to take advantage of this opportunity because of her learning disability.

[18] 
  Accordingly, this is a proper case, in accordance with  
 Khat 
 , supra, to refer the matter to a new Citizenship Judge because this court is not satisfied that relevant factors have been taken into account, namely the mental inability of the applicant to benefit from the LINC program and to improve her education in the English language. The court is without jurisdiction to recommend whether the applicant be granted or not granted citizenship. It is noted that nothing in this judgment should be taken to implicitly express an opinion whether or not the applicant ought be recommended for citizenship. That is strictly within the purview, expertise and jurisdiction of the Citizenship Judge reconsidering the case based on proper apprehension of the evidence and relevant factors.

[19] 
  Accordingly, the appeal is allowed. The matter is remitted to a new Citizenship Judge to consider under s. 15(1) of the  
 Act 
  whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister. 
 
 
 
 Appeal allowed.

legal_issues: The scope of appellate review concerning a citizenship judge's discretionary decisions regarding statutory exceptions to citizenship requirements.
Whether a citizenship judge adequately considered relevant medical evidence pertaining to an applicant's capacity to meet language proficiency requirements for naturalization.
The standard of review applicable to a citizenship judge's factual findings and their relation to supporting evidence.
The procedural requirements for reconsideration of a citizenship application in light of newly submitted evidence.
The jurisdictional limits of a court reviewing decisions related to citizenship applications and the distinction between appeals and judicial review.
The appropriate application of statutory provisions allowing for waivers of citizenship requirements based on compassionate grounds or undue hardship.
Whether a failure to consider relevant factors constitutes an error in the exercise of discretionary power by a citizenship judge.
factual_background: An individual, a citizen of Somalia and permanent resident of Canada, applied for Canadian citizenship.
The initial citizenship application was denied in 1997 due to insufficient knowledge of either official language.
The applicant appealed the initial denial, and the application was referred for reconsideration with new medical evidence regarding learning abilities.
A second citizenship judge denied the application in 2000, citing inadequate knowledge of Canada, its responsibilities and privileges, and insufficient knowledge of English or French.
The applicant’s medical records indicated illiteracy and a lack of formal schooling, with a professional opinion suggesting adult literacy programs were unsuitable.
A neuropsychological assessment indicated a lack of foundational skills necessary for language acquisition and limited capacity for new learning at age 52.

Evidence from a LINC (Language Instruction for Newcomers to Canada) instructor, not initially before the second citizenship judge, showed the applicant had been a student since 1997 with no progress and demonstrated confusion with the language.
The applicant appealed the second denial, leading to a review by the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division.

Applicants: The Citizenship Judge failed to properly consider relevant factors in exercising discretion under s. 15(1) of the Citizenship Act.
The Citizenship Judge misapprehended the medical evidence regarding the applicant’s inability to learn English due to a learning disability.
The applicant has been enrolled in the LINC program for two years, demonstrating an attempt to improve her education, but has been unable to benefit from it due to her learning disability.
The Citizenship Judge’s finding that the applicant has ‘many opportunities’ to improve her education is unreasonable given the medical evidence.
The applicant is unable to acquire the foundational skills necessary to benefit from adult English language education programs like LINC.
Respondents: The applicant does not have adequate knowledge of Canada and/or the responsibilities and privileges of citizenship.
The applicant does not have adequate knowledge of English or French.
The applicant has many opportunities in Canada to improve her education.
The applicant could benefit from programs like the ‘incredible Link program’ to improve her education.
The applicant’s medical opinion, while noting illiteracy and lack of schooling, does not preclude the possibility of improving education through available programs.

court_analysis: The court determined it had jurisdiction to review the Citizenship Judge’s decision despite the usual restriction on appealing discretionary decisions under s. 15(1) of the Citizenship Act, citing previous case law (Khat, Re) and a desire to avoid redundant legal proceedings.

The core issue was whether the Citizenship Judge properly considered the applicant’s medical inability to learn English when deciding whether to recommend the Minister exercise discretion to waive the language requirement.

The court found the Citizenship Judge’s decision was flawed because it failed to adequately consider the medical evidence establishing the applicant’s learning disability and its impact on her ability to benefit from language programs like LINC.

Specifically, the court deemed the Judge’s comparison of the applicant to other immigrants who successfully used LINC programs as “patently unreasonable” and “perverse” given the medical evidence demonstrating a lack of foundational skills necessary for such programs.

The court emphasized that the Judge misunderstood the significance of the applicant’s two-year enrollment in LINC, failing to recognize that her lack of progress was *due to* her learning disability, not a lack of effort or opportunity.

Applying the precedent set in Khat, Re, the court concluded that because relevant factors were not properly considered, the matter should be remitted to a new Citizenship Judge for reconsideration of whether to recommend discretionary relief under s. 15(1).

The court explicitly stated it was not expressing an opinion on whether citizenship *should* be granted, but rather that the decision must be based on a proper understanding and consideration of the evidence.
final_outcome: Matter remitted to a new Citizenship Judge to consider whether or not to recommend an exercise of discretion by the Minister under s. 15(1) of the Citizenship Act.
